What are simple token currencies in the context of Verus, and how do they relate to Ethereum ERC-20 tokens?

Simple token currencies in Verus are a type of currency that does not have any reserves. While they may not offer the same level of complexity as basket currencies, they still provide significant value due to their flexibility and customizability. These currencies can be used in a variety of use cases, such as decentralized crowdfunding mechanisms, and can be created with various parameters and subIDs.

In a decentralized simple token currency, the supply is static, whereas in a centralized version, the owner of the rootID can mint new tokens and anyone can burn existing ones. Additionally, simple token currencies can be used to create currencies that are mapped to Ethereum ERC-20 tokens, allowing for seamless transfer between the two platforms.

The Verus-Ethereum Bridge, a non-custodial bridge, enables the transfer of currencies and tokens between Verus and Ethereum. This means that any currency or token on Verus or any other PBaaS blockchain can be exported to Ethereum as an ERC-20 token, allowing it to be used in the Ethereum ecosystem. Conversely, any existing ERC-20 token can be mapped one-to-one as a Verus currency, allowing it to leverage the features of the Verus blockchain.

The Verus-Ethereum Bridge operates on a consensus-based system, ensuring that all tokens and currencies transferred between the two platforms are never in anyone's custody and are verified by consensus rules. This provides a secure and trustworthy means of transferring assets between Verus and Ethereum.
